text:
This is also surprising/somewhat evil, in the same vein as above:
```g1() = Dict{Symbol, Vector{Float64}}(
            :Z => [0.0, 0.0, 0.5],
            :A => [0.5, 0.5, 0.5])
g2() = Dict(:Z => [0.0, 0.0, 0.5],
            :A => [0.5, 0.5, 0.5])

@btime g1() # 254.061 ns (8 allocations: 896 bytes)
@btime g2() # 233.819 ns (6 allocations: 832 bytes)```
Adding the (correct) type annotation on the Dict leads to extra allocations :open_mouth:.
There's no difference if there's just one element in the Dict but for more than one element `g2` adds 2 allocations per new element, while `g1` just adds 1 allocation per element.

elements.text: This is also surprising/somewhat evil, in the same vein as above:
Adding the (correct) type annotation on the Dict leads to extra allocations

.
There's no difference if there's just one element in the Dict but for more than one element
g2
adds 2 allocations per new element, while
g1
just adds 1 allocation per element.

text:
especially surprising since the latter calls the former:
```Dict(ps::Pair{K,V}...) where {K,V} = Dict{K,V}(ps)```
:confused:

elements.text: especially surprising since the latter calls the former:
Dict(ps::Pair{K,V}...) where {K,V} = Dict{K,V}(ps)

text:
ok, that might be an artifact of the benchamrk, somehow:
```julia> ps = (:Z => [0.0, 0.0, 0.5],
                   :A => [0.5, 0.5, 0.5])
(:Z => [0.0, 0.0, 0.5], :A => [0.5, 0.5, 0.5])

julia> g1(ps) = Dict{Symbol, Vector{Float64}}(ps)
g1 (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> g2(ps) = Dict(ps)
g2 (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> @btime g1($(Ref(ps))[]);
  110.498 ns (4 allocations: 608 bytes)

julia> @btime g2($(Ref(ps))[]);
  131.759 ns (4 allocations: 608 bytes)```
these times look more reasonable

elements.text: ok, that might be an artifact of the benchamrk, somehow:

julia> ps = (:Z => [0.0, 0.0, 0.5],
                   :A => [0.5, 0.5, 0.5])
(:Z => [0.0, 0.0, 0.5], :A => [0.5, 0.5, 0.5])

julia> g1(ps) = Dict{Symbol, Vector{Float64}}(ps)
g1 (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> g2(ps) = Dict(ps)
g2 (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> @btime g1($(Ref(ps))[]);
  110.498 ns (4 allocations: 608 bytes)

julia> @btime g2($(Ref(ps))[]);
  131.759 ns (4 allocations: 608 bytes)
these times look more reasonable

text: That looks more reasonable, yeah; still strange though. Seems to be real for literals though?

elements.text: That looks more reasonable, yeah; still strange though. Seems to be real for literals though?

text: it may be happening something weird with the benchmarks.  for example, I prevented constant propagation with the use of `Ref(...)[]`, that's often useful to make fair benchmarks

text:
Having a day of surprises today... This one also just surprised me:
```write(stdout, :a)   # a1
write(stdout, :aa)  # aa2
write(stdout, :aaa) # aaa3```
What's with the extra numbers?
